column1: The Persian army would have to march round the edge of the gulf. They could not cut straight across the country
column2: because the ridge of mountains called Oeta rose up and barred their way. Indeed
column5: and precipices came down so near the seashore
column6: that in two places there was only room for one single wheel track between the steeps and the impassable morass that formed the border of the gulf on its south side. These two very narrow places were called the gates of the pass
column7: and were about a mile apart. There was a little more width left in the intervening space; but in this there were a number of springs of warm mineral water
column9: which were used for the sick to bathe in
column10: and thus the place was called Thermopylæ
